fields.description:
I had a 4.0 BETA instance where the index directory was no longer valid.  

When I went to the issue navigator it did....nothing.  It seems like I had NO issues as opposed to no index.

The old code you to crash with a 500 statck trace (BAD) but at least you know the indexes where bad.

We need to handle this better from a support impact point of view.

That or stop pretending that JIRA can run without an index!


Brenden asked me to raise this against JQL.  I am not sure its the culprit however.
fields.summary: Un activated Index directory has bad Issue navigator behaviour

fields.description:
Under Issue Linking I defined values for a new link type and clicked on "Add".

The browser popped up a window that says "Confirm?"

Are you sure you want to navigate away from this page?
You made changes ... they'll be lost (etc.).

If you click on "Ok", the new link type is still created.

I've tried this several times -- it continues to happen every time.
fields.summary: Clicking "Add" on Add New Link Type asks for confirmation to leave this page

fields.description: Custom field Date/Time: This comes with a calendar "picker" but you can type in the date and time instead if you use the correct format. We recently switched from 12- to 24-hour format. Here's the problem: If, for example, you type in 9:00 PM for the time, it comes up as 09:00 when instead it should come up as 21:00 (after clicking Save). Basically, instead of signaling an error, the "PM" is simply ignored. JIRA should either process the PM correctly or signal an error and force the user to enter the data again. (Note that specifying AM is not a problem as ignoring it doesn't change the time.)
fields.summary: Date/time input fields using 24-hour format ignore a typed-in 'pm' to give an incorrect time in the output

fields.description:
I downloaded the standalone 4.0.0-Beta1 tarball, extracted it in a directory, and skimmed the README file prior to starting it.

The browser quickly told me that I failed to configure jira.home (per JRA-16235).
However, the README didn't instruct me to take that step in the first place.

This new step should be added to the "BRIEF INSTALL GUIDE" section in the README files (.txt and .html).
fields.summary: Need to add info about jira.home to README files in top directory

fields.description: We have more than 400 projects and for users that require access to all of them would be nice to have a way of filter out the list of all projects. We usually need to use the browser's searching tool to find the text within the web page.
fields.summary: Add search box to filter out the list of all projects on the "Browse Project" screen.
When searching on date ranges in Jira, would be nice to be able to exclude weekends.

fields.description:
As part of the fix for issue [JRA-12525] warnings were added to various locations in JIRA when modifying mail handler settings. The warning message currently contains a link to the issue, however it should link to a page in the JIRA documentation that is a guide to setting the system variable.

The warning message is currently "The mail system property ''mail.mime.decodeparameters'' is not set to true. This may result in e-mail attachments with non-Latin filenames being ignored. See {0}JRA-12525{1} for details".
fields.summary: Create documentation page for system property mail.mime.decodeparameters=true warning

fields.description:
As outlined by the issue [JRA-12525] and [JRA-12534] the mail.mime.decodeparameters=true system property must be set for the mail handler to work correctly with emails from RFC 2231-compliant mail clients.

This system property will need to be manually set on WAR/EAR installations, so a step will need to be added to all the installation guides. 

The documentation already contains a guide for setting system properties on the various application servers [here|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Setting+properties+and+options+on+startup].

This step will also be required when updating to JIRA 4.0 from older versions.
fields.summary: Add the mail.mime.decodeparameters=true system property to WAR/EAR installation guides
Update the 4.0 upgrade guide with notes on how the fix searching and alike.

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Install JIRA 4.0
2. The dialog where user need to specify path for JIRA Home, enter any drive(non existing or CD drive).

Result:
1. It accept it without any error and installation proceeds

Expected:
1. A proper error message should be displayed and user should be prompted to enter the path again.
fields.summary: Providing an non-existing as path for JIRA_Home get accepted without any error message for windows installer

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Install JIRA 4.0
2. In the dialog where user needs to provide destination directory, suppose user writes just "jira" and not c:\jira

Result:
1. It give message but text separated in different lines(snapshot enclosed).

Expected:
1. Great if message can be shown as single line.
fields.summary: Formatting of the message given by the installer when user inputs invalid directory path is not correct.

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Install JIRA 4.0 beta

Result:
1. In no dialog hot keys are supported. User can use tab for moving between buttons. But presence of hot keys will allow user to navigate buttons quickly.

Expected:
1. Hot keys provided for all buttons.
fields.summary: Provide hot keys/keyboard support for windows installer

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Install JIRA Beta
2. In the screen where user need to provide JIRA destination directory, type any non-existing drive.

Result:
1: It give error message "you have write permission on the drive".

Expected:
1. A proper error message that "Drive doesn't exist" will be great.
fields.summary: Choosing an non-existing drive as destination directory for windows installer give wrong error message
updateIssue's handling of status updates should be done better

fields.description: Currently JIRA Administration User Browser provides only 'Email Contains' filter to find users based on partial email address. However, recently we are encountering several instances where we needed to find the user information based on user id or name (full or partial last and/or first name). Also, in some instance we are interested in finding all the  users based on partial user id. I am hoping this is not a difficult feature to implement, but it certainly quite useful.
fields.summary: JIRA Admininistration User Browser needs to provide filter 'Userid contains' and 'Name Contains' to search for users based on partial username and/or name.
DefaultPortalPageManager should use index to find portal pages by owner and name

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-17463].
  {panel}

(See linked issues for failing use cases.)

All of our indexing goes through the EnglishAnalyzer which passes the stream through several filters: lowercase, stop word removal, apostrophe removal, tokenizing on underscore and dash, and stemming. This works pretty well when you do a natural language kind of query but has numerous cases where it fails to return results that user experiences. What we need is some kind of secondary "exact text" index and use that to boost results.

One way would be to create a new "exact query" field in the SummaryIndexer, EnvironmentIndexer, and DescriptionIndexer and a PerFieldAnalyzerWrapper to use a "dumber" Analyzer that uses the WhitespaceTokenizer instead of the StandardTokenizer. Then we'd need to fix querying to understand that this new field exists. We could either overload the tilda operator and make it smart enough to search across both fields and combine the results in a smart way. Or we could make the equals operator handle text (right now it throws an exception). We'd also want some kind of UI configuration to enable/disable this since it changes behaviour and not everyone is going to want the new behaviour. This would likely break the existing unit tests and func tests for indexing and JQL so we'd need to fix those. We'd probably want to writer new Analyzers for German, French, and Spanish as well instead of just limiting this new behaviour to our English users. Possibly Chinese/Japanese/Korean as well. We'd want better func test coverage on searching in non-English languages to try to make sure this change doesn't have adverse effects for non-English users.

We'd also need to figure out how to handle text custom fields in all of this.

Another approach would be something more along the lines of the SynonymAnalyzer described in "Lucene in Action": have a single Analyzer emit multiple tokens with the same virtual position. Under the covers the Analyzer would multiplex TokenStreams from a "normal" Analyzer and a "dumb" Analyzer. I'm not sure if sharing the Reader between Tokenizers like that works, if not we'd might have to make changes to Lucene core. Having both kinds of tokens in the same index field seems like it OUGHT to end up giving better results for these "exact searches". But it might have adverse effects on normal search ordering. This approach would probably have less impact on JQL but has a higher risk of us running into shortcomings in Lucene APIs.
fields.summary: Better exact-text searching

For JIRA beta we have ship a gadget called "Create Issue". If user add "create issue" gadget without adding the JIRA instance as the consumer to itself, the gadget will fail. And user will see a progress bar spinning on the screen.

The user can add the running JIRA instance as consumer by going to http://<serverID>/plugins/servlet/oauth/consumers/add and add the current base url  in consumer.base.url text field. Click "Add" and you are ready to go

For adding the consumer, the user should be logged in as admin.

fields.description:
This request has come from my project management users on several occasions and I have not found a similar request in this database.  

*The Background* = 
Project Managers are required to have a corresponding JIRA number for each task within their project plans within my client site.  
Of course, they are using MS Project and their project plans are much like:
*Task*
* Sub Task
** Sub Sub Task
** Sub Sub Task
* Sub Task
** Sub Sub Task


My users want to be able to completely match this structure within their JIRA projects so when they pull up a main task, the subsequent sub tasks and sub-sub tasks appear under the issue.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-17451].

JIRA doesn't deal well with Microsoft products when being served over SSL when serving non-HTML resources. This is caused by a mismatch between how Microsoft treats Cache-Control headers and how JIRA sets them.

By default everything goes through the JiraCachingFilter and have no-cache and no-store added to the headers. Setting those means IE doesn't allow documents served over SSL to be stored to disk. This not only means you can't right-click-save them but if they are handled by external applications (Excel, Word, etc) you get error messages that are often strange and difficult to decipher.

So far we've had a piecemeal approach to fixing this: a customer reports a problem and we fix that one thing. First it was Word documents, then Excel, then RSS, then Workflows.

It would be better to consolidate our caching strategy into a central place, much as JiraCachingFilter works today, but with the knowledge of how to handle these other resources properly. Additionally some kind of Windows based selenium tests around all of these would be nice to help verify we don't ever regress, especially since none of our normal testing involves SSL.
fields.summary: Better handling of non-html over SSL

If one subscribes to a filter shared by a different user and then the filter is being unshared, the subscriber can't unsubscribe from it. Moreover, JIRA still sends the subscription messages.

Also, the subscription is still visible in the View Subscriptions page for the owner of the unshared filter.

A possible workaround this problem is to request the owner to share again the filter and then remove the subscription.

Implement Startup Check for data which is too old to be upgraded by the current version of the app

fields.description:
I'm not sure whether there's already a task for this for the 4.0 Upgrade Guide, but there needs to be a separate document (ie not just related to 4.0) that outlines how to do multi-staged data upgrades. We have just implemented a mechanism which locks JIRA on start up if the data is older than the minimum required version, and also prevents you from importing data which is too old.

When these events occur, an error message is displayed to the user telling them that their data is too old, but we do not have the room to describe to them how to go about remedying the problem. And since we don't want to have change the message for every release of JIRA, we should have a standalone document which outlines the process for doing these upgrades. I have tentatively used the URL {{http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/JIRA+Upgrade+Guide+For+Old+Versions}} but of course this can change. The URL is defined in the {{external-link.properties}} file.
fields.summary: Need additional documentation on how to do multi-staged data upgrades

fields.description: Installer does not substitute <jira_service_id> in the {start_service, stop_service}.bat scripts when the "install JIRA as a service" is turned off. This makes these scripts useless if the user later decides to start JIRA as a service. Having a quick look at the installer, it appears that we only replace <jira_service_id> when the installer installs the service. We should just always make the substitution.

fields.description:
The Calendar Plugin (attached) uses JS injection for its active elements (links, AJAX, etc). 

Somehow, the "href" attribute in some of the links generated by the plugin's portlet get overwritten.

Due to that, the calendar works as a project tab panel but not as a portlet. Both of them are using the same JS and Velocity templates.

If you need to reproduce this with a plugin, you can install the JIRA Calendar Plugin by copying the JARs below to WEB-INF/lib:

# [jira-calendar-plugin-1.10-SNAPSHOT.jar|^jira-calendar-plugin-1.10-SNAPSHOT.jar]
# [ical4j-0.9.18.jar|^ical4j-0.9.18.jar]

[Here's a JIRA export|^jira-export.xml] that you can use as test data. You'll see versions and JIRA issues rendered for May 2009 in the calendars generated by the plugin.

To further illustrate this, I've provided two screen shots, highlighting how differently the same code works as:

* [A project tab panel|^project-tab-panel.png]
* [A portlet|^portlet.png]
fields.summary: Some links in portlets get "overwritten" when rendered as a gadget

2. Add 2-3 gadgets and configure data for it. Like selecting filters/project and other settings.
3. Share the dashboard with all user.
4. Login as user B and search the dashboard. User can see the dashboard and all gadgets with data. Click on "Modify preferences" icon on the bottom right end side.

Result:
1. It allow the viewing user to edit the preferences. I tried with filter results and Issues: Recently Created Chart.
2. For filter results, atleast it give error message after displaying the data but for other gadget, modification of data works without any error.

Expected:
1. Only the owner of dashboard should be allowed to modify the preferences for gadgets.
2. Dashboard shared with others is read-only.
fields.summary: User viewing the shared dashboard is able to edit the preferences of gadgets on it.

fields.description:
When we patch JIRA, it still often has the same build number so you are never sure if the fix is in!

So we should add a class to hold patch information and make that information turn up in the logs and system info patch
fields.summary: Ability for support to easily tell if a patch has been applied

fields.description:
1. Log-in to JIRA as user A.
2. Save a filter and don't share it with other users.
3. Add a gadget "Filter Results" and in the preferences select the filter for data.
4. Share the dashboard with everybody.
5. Login as user B. Search and view the user A dashboard.

Result
1. It give error message "Unfortunately, one or more of your preferences are now unavailable. Please update your preferences, or remove gadget by clicking delete from the title bar above."
2. Screenshot enclosed.

Expected:
1. Error message should be user friendly. This message is just confusing user. We can message like you don't have permission to view the data or the filter showing the data is not shared.
fields.summary: Error handling is not proper when dashboard having gadgets showing private data(thru filters) is shared with other users.

fields.description:
Steps:.
1. Launch JIRA 4.0 and open/create a dashboard. 
2. Add "Filter Results" gadget from gadget browser.
3. Leave the "Number of result" field blank. Click "Save" to save the preferences.

Result.
1. It gives an internal server error message.
2. Same error occur if user tries to save preferences with decimal digit. 
3. Trying to save the preferences with 0 or -ve number, doesn't give any error messages. Just set the focus back on preferences window.
4. Will there be a limit to the number of issue, a user can display?

Expected:
1. A user friendly error message should be provided and user should be promoted to input the missing field.
fields.summary: Trying to save preferences for "Filter Results" with number of results set to empty give internal server error
https links generated in gadgets include a redundant :443
Limit the quick search to the results of the issue navigator query

fields.description:
There are a few readme files in JIRA.

Standalone/tomcat/README.txt
Standalone/tomcat/README.html
Standalone/external-source/README.txt
source/README.txt
...
+ Many more.

We will need to look through these text files that we include in the build and ensure they are up todate. It appears that the doco URL also needs to be updated in these files.
fields.summary: The readme files in JIRA need to be updated for JIRA 4.0.
After Data import, the "Base URL" setting should stay the same as before the import.

fields.description:
Due to a bug in firefox not respecting the combination of Expires and Cache-control headers, when used to achieve browser-only long-term caching in accordance with modern best practice [caching control|http://code.google.com/p/doctype/wiki/ArticleHttpCaching], firefox does not cache the avatar image at all.

We must workaround this problem by removing the Expires header which is replaced by Cache-control for all but legacy proxies.

Once the fix has been widely enough deployed in firefox, we can put the correct code back.
fields.summary: Project Avatar images are not cached in Firefox

Since 2002 there has been a stray Thumbs.db file lurking in the JIRA distribution:

-rw-r--r-- 0/0           22016 2009-04-23 11:30 atlassian-jira-enterprise-3.13.4/webapp/images/icons/attach/Thumbs.db

Could we please remove it? It's making lintian unhappy in my debian package.

Add capability to bulk edit to allow pre-pending or appending text to text fields.

fields.description:
When clicking on Version, the sorting seems quite random. At least if one use sub-tasks. 

Could current sorting be changed into at least group sub-task beneath parent? Or even better, make it configurable.
fields.summary: Improved sorting in version view

fields.description:
Step:
1. Login in JIRA.
2. Click on "Find Issue" and switch to advanced editing. Suppose user want to query for all issues in project Test-JIRA
3. Type a Query project = Test-JIRA. The user interface guide you to write this query.
4. Click "Search"

Result:
1. It give error message "Unable to parse the query 'project=Test-JIRA' with thrown exception: 'An error occured while parsing the JQL 'project=Test-JIRA'.'."
2. Just put quotes around the project name it work fine.
3. For project with spaces, the UI put quotes by itself but as there is no space this query should work without quotes.

Expected:
1. Query should work without error message.
fields.summary: JQL autocomplete has a bug where it is not adding quotes around values that contain the '-' character

fields.description:
Steps:
1. JIRA 4.0 has concept of JIRA_HOME.
2.  Before the user starts the startup.bat script, he/she needs to set the JIRA_HOME path in jira-application.properties
3. Try to setup the JIRA_HOME path with frontslash(windows default). c:\xyz\....

Result:
1. It give error message when user start the JIRA server.

Expected:
1. Java needs path in backslash(Mac way). Providing path like c:/xyz/... solves the issue.
2. We need to document this to avoid confusion among windows user.
fields.summary: JIRA_HOME path in windows needs to be specified using backslash(or as Mac) and not as default windows way. Needs to document it to avoid confusion.

fields.description:
Steps:
1. Launch JIRA.
2. Add Activity stream gadget for JIRA.
3. Highlight any issue in "Activity Stream" gadget and click on "Comment" icon.
4. Don't type anything in comment text and click "Save" button.

Result:
1. It give internal server error. Screen shot attached.

Expected:
1.A proper user friendly warning message should be there.
fields.summary: Activity Stream gadget give internal server error if try to save with empty comment.

fields.description:
The legacy show saved gadgets portlet is now being wrapped in a gadget. However, this chops off the bottom row of the list of issues (possibly more, i can't really tell). Furthermore, when I click the name of the filter it should take me to issue navigator showing the filter, but instead it gives a 404, because it is going to the wrong address: https://extranet.atlassian.com/jira/plugins/servlet/gadgets/IssueNavigator.jspa instead of https://extranet.atlassian.com/jira/secure/IssueNavigator.jspa

Combined, this makes it quite annoying to do my job as I am constantly checking these saved filters on my dashboard.

fields.summary: Make modz detector dump modification info into log on startup

fields.description:
Hello all,

a little improvement that could make Jira management easier would be to add a little _free space left on device_ check before initiating an XML export/backup. While it would be rather difficult to estimate the final size of the export and confirm whether it would fit or not, a reasonable 10% low threshold could help.

In the case of scheduled XML backups it could even stop the service and start alerting administrators with a mail or a dashboard warning.


Best Regards,
Edoardo
fields.summary: Warn administrators about low disk space in the XML backup procedure

fields.description:
After completing a bulk move the user in redirected back to the navigator. This navigator redirect URL does not appear to be correct:

http://localhost:8090/jira/secure/views/bulkedit/IssueNavigator.jspa?subTaskPhase=false

as compared to the correct

http://localhost:8090/jira/secure/IssueNavigator.jspa

There does not appear to be any errors. Webwork seems to be working some of its voodoo here to find the action at the wrong URL.

This may also affect other bulk operations.
fields.summary: Redirected in invalid (but working) URL after bulk move.

fields.description:
JIRA's 'forgot password' feature should not disclose whether a username actually exists in the system. One can use the 'forgotten password' functionality to see which users
exist or which don't. The screen states "It's OK! Simply enter your username below and a new password will be sent to you via email. If you have forgotten your username you can retrieve it here."

If you enter a non-existant username, it currently warns "No user with that username exists". Instead, the feature should say the same thing whether a username exists or not, with a message similar to:
"Please check the email address you signed up with in a few minute's time. To protect your security, we can't reveal whether that username actually exists or not."
fields.summary: Improve security by having Forgot Password feature no longer confirm that a given username exists

fields.description:
The Bugzilla importer contains some "work history" code, which, judging from the comments in the code, hasn't been tested much.  I found two problems with it:
(1) It never gets called, whether or not you tick the box to import work history in the UI!
(2) Once you fix that, it takes the "remaining estimate" from Bugzilla and sets it as the "time spent" in Jira, which is wrong.

I've believe I've fixed these myself as part of getting our Bugzilla import working:

To fix (1), I inserted this snippet into "bugzilla_choosemappings.jsp":

<ui:component name="'workHistory'" value="workHistory" template="hidden.jsp" />

Right after the other parameters (enableNotifications ... onlyNew).

To fix (2), I changed this line of code:

issueObject.setTimeSpent(new Long(time_remaining));

to this: 

issueObject.setEstimate(new Long(time_remaining));

in BugzillaImportBean.java
fields.summary: "Import work history" feature doesn't work in the Bugzilla importer

fields.description:
We have a potential problem with searching for comments in JQL now because the way we do it is:
# Run the comment search over the comment index
# Collect the issue ids for the matching documents
# Build up an issue query that will match any of the collected ids and then run it over the issue index.

If the comment query is too generic (e.g. {{comment !~ "awordthatwontexist"}}) we are likely to get many matching issue ids on a large instance of JIRA, which then translates to a large query for the issue index. At the moment, we have the maximum number of terms a query can contain set to 65,000. But on an instance with more than this number of issues, a query with that many terms could be a not-too-rare occurrence. Then, on top of the number of issues, there are other factors which can influence the number of terms used, namely how complex the permissions filter for that user is (which is a function of how many projects, how many issue security schemes, how many groups the user is a member of, etc).

What actually happens is: when a BooleanQuery is being constructed and exceeds the maximum number of terms, a runtime exception is thrown ({{TooManyClauses}}). This is not currently trapped anywhere in JIRA code.

We suspect that this might happen a bit more often now with irresponsible use of the comment search, but in reality this could also occur due to say a JQL function that generates too many terms to search for. Ideally, we want a way to report back to the user how this happened, so that they can modify their query.

It would be best to handle this in a standard, preferably single way, across all ClauseQueryFactorys. However, this only monitors the queries generated for each specific terminal clause - so we would also need handling when the clauses are combined. But by that stage, we've lost the insight into which clause caused the problem (or contributed most to the excess of terms). We have a similar problem when, after combining all the queries, we then add on the permissions filter for the user.
fields.summary: Handle Lucene queries that have too many clauses in such a way that the user can be notified about it
